data.title: I Love You, I Don't (1976)
data.meta_description: The petite waitress Johnny works and lives in a truck-stop, where she's lonely and longs for love. She develops a crush on the garbage truck driver Krassky, although her sleazy boss Boris warns her that he's gay.
data.text:
earnestly regret not having seen this before writing my piece about a transmasc cinematic canon… if there’s ever a follow up i’m absolutely writing about this because it’s fucking insane. if you read the Jane Birkin character as a gay trans man - not at all hard considering she literally says “i’m a boy!” at one point - than this comes across as exceptionally progressive. of course this could just as easily be Serge Gainsbourg making a movie about how his wife is so hot she could seduce a gay man but i feel like i would do that too if my wife was Jane Birkin. but also there’s something interesting about an almost certainly heterosexual man making a movie…

Like a Godard film if Godard was only interested in fucking.

I think it probably all meant more to Serge Gainsbourg than it means to me, though the central theme seems to be that Serge Gainsbourg’s real-life partner (Jane Birkin) is so hot that she can make gay men sort of a bit straight for a while. The central gay guy is rubbish collector Joe Dallesandro, who keeps pretending that Birkin’s androgynous barmaid, Johnny, is a boy, and trying to do her up the bum. This makes his psychotic ex-boyfriend jealous. They never reach climax, though, because the pain makes her scream so loudly that they keep being ejected from hotels. This is what passes for a running joke in…

Wow. Not quite sure what message French musician/singer-songwriter/director Serge Gainsbourg is sending in this, his first feature. Is it a subversive commentary on sexual fluidity and gender? Or is it exploitative, misogynistic and homophobic.? At times, I was uncomfortable, for sure. But I nonetheless found it fascinating and creative.

The setting is a desolate desert-like unidentified wasteland of garbage pits with buzzing flies and scavenger crows, aimless men, and women who strip and sell their bodies. A gay trash transporter (Warhol's Factory stud Joe Dallesandro) and his boyfriend (Hugues Quester) - both rough around the edges - stop at a truck stop to fuel up and grab a burger. A young androgynous waitress (Jane Birkin) has an immediate erotic attraction…
